sanskrit:
न हि प्रपश्यामि ममापनुद्याद्यच्छोकमुच्छोषणमिन्द्रियाणाम् ।
अवाप्य भूमावसपत्नमृद्धं राज्यं सुराणामपि चाधिपत्यम् ॥८॥
transliteration:
na hi prapaśyāmi mamāpanudyād yac chokam ucchoṣaṇam indriyāṇām |
avāpya bhūmāv asapatnam ṛddhaṁ rājyaṁ surāṇām api cādhipatyam ||8||
translation: I do not see what can remove this grief that is drying up my senses, even if I were to obtain unrivaled and prosperous sovereignty on earth, or even lordship over the gods.
commentary:
In this verse, Arjuna expresses the depth of his despair and confusion. He declares that even the greatest worldly achievements—an uncontested kingdom on earth or even sovereignty over the celestial realms—would not dispel the sorrow that is withering his senses. This statement reveals that Arjuna's crisis is not merely emotional but existential and spiritual in nature. His grief has paralyzed his capacity for action and clouded his discrimination.

This verse marks a crucial turning point in the dialogue. Arjuna has moved from presenting rational arguments against fighting to acknowledging his complete inability to resolve his inner conflict. The 'drying up of the senses' (ucchoṣaṇam indriyāṇām) indicates a state of complete dejection where even the faculties of perception and action have become impaired. By stating that no material gain could alleviate his suffering, Arjuna inadvertently reveals that his problem requires a spiritual solution, not a worldly one.

This verse sets the stage for Krishna's teachings that follow. Arjuna's admission of helplessness and his recognition that external achievements cannot resolve internal conflicts creates the perfect condition for receiving spiritual wisdom. His state represents the crisis that often precedes genuine spiritual inquiry—when one realizes that conventional solutions are inadequate for addressing the fundamental questions of existence, duty, and the nature of the self.
speaker: Arjuna
